results.headline: Just About Anything for Love
results.summary_short: “Lucky” is an off-kilter romantic comedy suggesting that women will do just about anything for love.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lucky

results.headline: Burdened in a Ravaged South Africa
results.summary_short: “Life, Above All” traces the tribulations of a 12-year-old overburdened with responsibilities in a South Africa racked with AIDS.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Life, Above All

results.headline: The Cult of Running
results.summary_short: “Hood to Coast” is a documentary about a nutty relay race in Oregon.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hood To Coast

results.headline: A Kindhearted Man in a Small Town
results.summary_short: “Girlfriend” is about a young man with Down syndrome who lives in a small Massachusetts town, and the role is played by the man who inspired the story.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Girlfriend

results.headline: Class Dismissed
results.summary_short: Childhood ends with tears and howls and swirls of smoke, the shock of mortality and bittersweet smiles in the grave, deeply satisfying final movie in the “Harry Potter” series.
results.display_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2

results.headline: No Sleep for a Beauty Who Seeks Adventure
results.summary_short: In Catherine Breillat’s “Sleeping Beauty” the princess doesn’t fall into a 100-year slumber, she hits the road for some adventure.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sleeping Beauty

results.headline: So, Would It Hurt You to Go See a Documentary About a Yiddish Writer?
results.summary_short: “Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness” is a film biography not just of a writer but of a culture.
results.display_title: Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness

results.headline: Some Humans and the Chimp They Loved and Tormented
results.summary_short: James Marsh’s documentary “Project Nim” is about a chimpanzee, but we mostly see humans behaving badly.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Project Nim

results.headline: Government Oversight in Farming
results.summary_short: In the documentary “Farmageddon,” Kristin Canty seeks to show that agribusiness is employing government agencies to harass independent farmers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Farmageddon

results.headline: A Group’s Formation and Dissolution
results.summary_short: The actor Michael Rapaport recounts the history of the influential hip-hop ensemble A Tribe Called Quest.
results.display_title: Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of A Tribe Called Quest

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of A Tribe Called Quest

results.headline: Dating Tips From Friends at the Zoo? Of Courserous
results.summary_short: Rejection makes the heart more likely to seek advice from trusted friends in “Zookeeper,” a movie about relationships of the platonic and romantic kind.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Zookeeper

results.headline: Looking for Answers Before He Leaps
results.summary_short: A film that looks to ask questions about faith and the existence of God, “The Ledge” features a man threatening to leap off a building.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ledge

results.headline: Young, Cute and Menaced, Per Usual
results.summary_short: In “John Carpenter’s The Ward” there is much to remind the viewer of a director’s past heyday.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ward

results.headline: Grant a Few Rights, See What Happens?
results.summary_short: Paul Giamatti plays King John, who signed the Magna Carta and regretted it, in “Ironclad,” a medieval battle film directed by Jonathan English.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ironclad

results.headline: A Treatise on Issues of the Workplace. Not.
results.summary_short: In “Horrible Bosses,” a foul-mouthed and frequently funny new comedy of male resentment directed by Seth Gordon, employees plot revenge.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Horrible Bosses

results.headline: Amid War, Fierce Adversaries of the Creepy-Crawly Variety
results.summary_short: The Sri Lankan filmmaker Sanjeewa Pushpakumara’s debut feature, “Flying Fish,” follows three largely unconnected stories of civilians struggling in his war-torn country.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flying Fish

results.headline: The Humbling of a Powerful Frenchman
results.summary_short: “Rapt,” a French thriller opening Wednesday at Film Forum, is about the shockwaves that result from the kidnapping of an industrialist.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rapt!

results.headline: A Rural Homecoming Stirs Trouble
results.summary_short: Michael Tully directs and stars in “Septien,” a Southern gothic tale of a man who returns unannounced to his family’s farm after a long absence.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Septien

results.headline: Violence Close at Hand Shakes a Bucolic Setting
results.summary_short: “Small Town Murder Songs” follows a born-again police officer with inner demons in rural Ontario.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Small Town Murder Songs

results.headline: Seeking a Path to Justice
results.summary_short: “Crime After Crime” favors the personal over the political, creating a no-frills portrait of a stoic and remarkably unembittered woman.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crime After Crime
